Hadu

Hadu

Authors: Huong Nguyen, Cullin Lam, Kody Thach, Son Nguyen

An enhanced music player built with ReactJS, Genius, UrbanDictionary, Spotify API.

Goals

  • To build a music player that allows users to quickly stream, lookup lyrics, and meaning of particular words. In particular, we decided to use the UrbanDictionary API to define slang words that are found commonly in today's popular songs and lastly Spotify API to stream music.

Inspiration

  • With sites such as Genius and a plethora of lyrics sites, we decided to combine several of these services into a single streaming music player.

What it does

  • Streams music using Spotify API, fetches lyrics via Genius API, and looks up words using Urban Dictionary.

How we built it

  • React
  • Node Js

Challenges we ran into

  • Using web API's
  • learning how to use React
  • Oauth

Accomplishments that we're proud of

We were able to implement the player with Spotify and the Urban Dictionary API.

What's next for Hadu

  • Incorporate Genius API,
  • Provide option to define words with other services such as Wiki
  • Allow user login with Oauth so the whole song can be streamed
  • Improve look and feel

How to run

  1. git clone https://github.com/kidculli/SharkHackUrbanGenius.git
  2. npm install
  3. npm start
  4. Open a browser and go to localhost:8080

Built With

  • built-with-react
  • spotify
  • genius
  • node.js

Try it out

  • github.com
Implemented functions to call Spotify, Genius, and Urban Dictionary API's and parse response.

Simmons Says

Inspiration

We had a lot of hardware parts, and we wanted to make a fun and interactive game that incorporated most of them.

What it does

Player 1 inputs a series of buttons that player 2 must copy in order to tie. If player two matches, you both NAILED it.. like a hammerhead shark!

How we built it

We used 3 bread boards, one arduino uno, a NeoPixel Wheel, multiple resistors and buttons, a red LED, and a lot of creativity to come up with this project. We take inputs from the buttons, display the inputs on the NeoPixel Wheel, and then compare the matching sequence on the computer through the Arduino uno.

Challenges we ran into

First we spent the first 3 hours pursuing a project that would take a month to complete, so we changed the scope of the project to something more simple. We then switched from using a Raspberry Pi to the Arduino Uno due to issues connecting to the WiFi though the Simmon's VPN. We then ran into an error with the circuitry on our board early this morning, and resolved it at 1 PM. We then only had 2 hours to refine our code.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

Finishing our project on time with a deliverable! Getting an awesome visual output! Having code that works!

What we learned

Its best to have a more concrete idea when you start than trying to formulate one as you go. Also, having mentors that are knowledgable is a huge advantage when it comes to debugging and helping with issues. Also coming with a team with a broad skill set may also help the scope of the project.

What's next for Simmons Says

Making the game code itself better, adding sound effects, displaying the result of the game on the LiquidCrystal LCD

Built With

  • arduino

Try it out

  • drive.google.com
Shark Tails of Love

• Home screen

The Goblin Sharks

Anais Alvarez, Yazi Dacosta, Shen Gao, Rebecca Haralson

Category

Best UX/UI Design

Inspiration

After much discussion about our interests and backgrounds, the Goblin Sharks decided to create a web game based on the popular Japanese dating sims. During the game’s development, the team focused on UX/UI with an emphasis on creating gender-neutral characterizations for diverse user inclusion. For example, no gendered pronouns were used in this game, and the character names are meant to be gender neutral.

What it does

The look of “Shark Tails of Love” is based entirely on the dating sim format with genre tropes used in the creation of shark characters. In this first person simulation, the player takes the role of a new student at Simmons Academy, an underwater institute for sharks. The user hopes to make friends and potentially find a mate.

How we built it

We built the website using HTML, CSS, and Javascript.

Challenges we ran into

We were not sure of the direction we wanted to take the project in terms of how to implement its features. We spent hours trying to decide and research on possible ways of bringing our idea to life.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

It works as it should!

What we learned

We learned that it's important to know how to apply your skills without trying to make things/concepts more complicated than they are. It was a good experience for us to combine front-end and back-end design.

What's next for Shark Tails of Love

As this is a game, we can look into implementing and integrating further levels. Who knows???

Built With

  • javascript
  • html
  • css
  • photoshop

Try it out

  • web.simmons.edu

Spend Me Not

Inspiration

Spend Me Not (SMN) was inspired by a common dilemma noticed among team members: After we receive our paychecks, we're tempted to blow a lot of it away on things we don't need or can't afford. We decided to come up with a mobile solution to combat this situation...

What it does

Enter SMN! The essential goal of this product is to tell the end user when they are getting close to spending their allotted budget. By linking their bank accounts to the app, users will be able to accurately see how much money is being spent in real time. Not only that, SMN will also send alarms and notifications when you approach or surpass your pre-set "threshold of pain."

How we built it

This project is SMN's wireframe. That is to say, it's a HTML5 & CSS3 mock-up of a basic UX with our product.

Challenges we ran into

Many members of our team were not experienced in web development and had to essentially learn HTML and CSS overnight.

Accomplishments that we're proud of

Our team met these challenges head on and, though we didn't complete our wireframe, everyone is able to walk out of this event with a good chunk of knowledge in basic web development with today's modern tools.

What we learned

HTML5 & CSS3.

What's next for Spend Me Not

This project is free to be built upon by other members of the SharkHack community, however at this time the team has no intentions of further developing the project.

Built With

  • html5
  • css3

Try it out

shark side scroller

Welcome to the angelsharks wiki!

This is a project done in P5 and and javascript. We were given 24 hours to build whatever we wanted with in some categories. We decided to build a side-scroller that incorporated the hackathon mascot, Sharks! We used P5 for the physics of the water and air and they respond accordingly by slowing down the shark in water and allowing him to fly thru the air. What we learned is a lot about JS and Github. We had a ton of problems getting JS to run as we had never really touched this technology.We covered many topics such as collision detection algorithms, physics in P5, and how to manage many different sprites that needed to interact. By the end we were happy with what we produced. If you want to leave any suggestions for improvements please do!

Thanks for checking out our side scrolling shark game!

  • javascript

Where To?

Inspiration

Aren't you tired of visiting multiple websites to stay in the loop? "Where To?' is the site to browse and visit, saving you from searching in every corner of the Internet.

What it does

Where To? compiles event data from various ruby gems, including Eventbrite and Eventful.

Challenges we ran into

  • Our team decided to learn all new technologies, including Ruby on Rails, CSS, and HTML. This was a challenging and worthwhile undertaking.
  • Many APIs did not have the fields we desired and the form of the data varied significantly.

Accomplishments that I'm proud of

Our team had many "firsts"!

  • Maddie's first hackathon.
  • Addie's first time developing for the web.
  • Dod implemented his first web scraper.
  • Maryann's first time using web APIs.
  • Everyone's first Ruby on Rail application!

What's next for Where To?

Aren't you tired of having to spend time manually adding different events to your calendar? We'd like to tackle this next! Additionally, we plan to incorporate events from additional APIs, inform users of the sources of the events, and offer a variety of filters. Go Bluesharks!

Debug Your Schedule

This program is in the running for the UO/UX Hack category.

Our inspiration was to help other students organize their time in order to complete their assignments in a complete and effective way.

It was built with python and was staged with the mock up site balsamiq.

The team had to expand our knowledge of the Python language after only 3 weeks of exposure to the language. We also had to learn how to use balsamiq from scratch. It was also our first time experiencing and participating in a hackathon.

We were given the opportunity to embrace the computer science community. We made a product that runs successfully and has room to expand.

We learned how to merge collaborative work.

Hopefully, it will go on to assist every student that needs help managing their time or learning new study skills.
